substep.cmd: Open /etc/default/serviced in a text editor.

Save the file, and then close the editor.

step.cmd: Verify that the host implements the 64-bit version of the x86 instruction set.

choices.choice: If the output is x86_64, the architecture is 64-bit. Proceed to the next step
If the output is i386/i486/i586/i686, the architecture is 32-bit. Stop this procedure and select a different host.

step.cmd: Add an entry to /etc/hosts for localhost, if necessary.

step.cmd: Authenticate to the Docker Hub repository.
step.info: Replace User with the name of your Docker Hub account.
step.stepresult: The docker command prompts you for the Docker Hub password, and saves a hash of the credentials in the $HOME/.docker/config.json file (root user account).

step.cmd: Specify an alternate private subnet for , if necessary.

info.p: The default private subnet may already be in use in your environment. The following variable configures serviced to use an alternate subnet:

substep.cmd: Locate the SERVICED_VIRTUAL_ADDRESS_SUBNET declaration, and then change the value to an IPv4 network address in CIDR notation.
substep.stepxmp: The following example shows the line to change: # SERVICED_VIRTUAL_ADDRESS_SUBNET=10.3
substep.info: For example, change the value to 203.0.113.0/20.

step.cmd: Configure to serve as the master.

info.p: The following variable configures serviced to serve as master:

substep.cmd: Find the SERVICED_MASTER declaration, and then change the value from 0 to 1.
substep.stepxmp: The following example shows the line to change: # SERVICED_MASTER=0

step.cmd: Create an LVM thin pool for Docker data.
step.info: For more information about the serviced-storage command, see .
step.stepxmp: To use an entire block device or partition for the thin pool, replace Device-Path with the device path: serviced-storage create-thin-pool docker Device-Path
To use 50GB of an LVM volume group for the thin pool, replace Volume-Group with the name of an LVM volume group: serviced-storage create-thin-pool --size=50G docker Volume-Group
step.stepresult: On success, the result is the device mapper name of the thin pool, which always starts with /dev/mapper.

step.cmd: Add a delegate host.

stepxmp.p: Replace Hostname-Or-IP with the hostname or IP address of the delegate host to add:
If you enter a hostname, all hosts in your cluster must be able to resolve the name, either through an entry in /etc/hosts, or through a nameserver on your network.

step.cmd: Determine whether the CPU resources are sufficient.

substep.cmd: Display the total number of CPU cores.
Compare the available resources with the requirements for a master host.
substep.info: For more information, refer to the .

step.cmd: Determine whether the CPU resources support the AES instruction set.
step.stepresult:
For optimal performance, the result of the preceding commands must match the total number of CPU resources available on the host. If the result is 0, performance is severely degraded.
If the result is 0 and the candidate host is a virtual machine, the managing hypervisor may be configured in Hyper-V compatibility mode. Check the setting and disable it, if possible, or select a different host.

step.cmd: Determine whether the available, unused storage is sufficient.

substep.cmd: Display the available storage devices.
Compare the available storage with the amount required for a delegate host in your deployment.
substep.info: For more information, refer to the .

step.cmd: Verify that name resolution works on this host.
step.stepresult: If the result is not a valid IPv4 address, add an entry for the host to the network nameserver, or to /etc/hosts.

step.cmd: Verify that the host has adequate storage space for Docker temporary files and audit logging.

substep.cmd: Display the amount of space available in /tmp.
substep.info: Docker requires 10GB of storage for temporary files, and the installation process includes instructions to link the Docker temporary directory to /tmp.
substep.stepresult: Typically, /tmp is mounted on the root filesystem, /.

substep.cmd: Display the amount of space available in /var/log.
substep.info: By default, requires 10GB of space for audit logging in /var/log. The amount of space required for audit logs, and their location, is configurable. .
substep.stepresult: Like /tmp, /var/log is typically mounted on the root filesystem, /.

step.stepresult: If the result does not include a minimum of 10GB of space for Docker temporary files and 10GB for audit logging, stop this procedure and select a different host.

step.cmd: Verify that the host has adequate storage space on the root filesystem.
step.stepresult: If the result does not include a minimum of 35GB of available space, stop this procedure and select a different host.

step.cmd: Determine whether the available memory and swap is sufficient.

substep.cmd: Display the available memory.
Compare the available memory and swap space with the amount required for a master host in your deployment.

step.stepresult: If the result does not meet minimum requirements, stop this procedure and select a different host.

step.cmd: Ensure the host has a persistent numeric ID.
step.info: Skip this step if you are installing a single-host deployment.
Each host in a cluster must have a unique host ID, and the ID must be persistent (not change when the host reboots).
step.stepresult: Record the ID for comparison with other hosts in the cluster.

step.cmd: Disable the firewall, if necessary.
step.info: This step is required for installation but not for deployment. For more information, refer to the .

substep.cmd: Determine whether the firewalld service is enabled.

ul.li: If the result includes Active: inactive (dead), the service is disabled. Proceed to the next step.
If the result includes Active: active (running), the service is enabled. Perform the following substep.

substep.cmd: Disable the firewalld service.

stepxmp.codeblock: systemctl stop firewalld && systemctl disable firewalld

substep.stepresult: On success, the preceding commands display messages similar to the following example: rm '/etc/systemd/system/dbus-org.fedoraproject.FirewallD1.service' rm '/etc/systemd/system/basic.target.wants/firewalld.service'

step.cmd: Determine whether the installed operating system release is supported.

choices.choice: If the result includes 7.1, 7.2, or 7.3 proceed to the next step.
If the result does not include 7.1, 7.2, or 7.3, select a different host, and then start this procedure again.

step.cmd: Update the Linux kernel, if necessary.

substep.cmd: Determine which kernel version is installed.
substep.stepresult: If the result is lower than 3.10.0-327.22.2.el7.x86_64, perform the following substep.

substep.cmd: Update the kernel, and then restart the host.
substep.info: The following commands require internet access or a local mirror of operating system packages.

stepxmp.codeblock: yum makecache fast && yum update kernel && reboot

step.cmd: Enable persistent storage for log files, if desired.
step.info: By default, RHEL/CentOS systems store log data only in memory or in a ring buffer in the /run/log/journal directory. By performing this step, log data persists and can be saved indefinitely, if you implement log file rotation practices. For more information, refer to your operating system documentation. The following commands are safe when performed during an installation, before Docker or are installed or running. To enable persistent log files after installation, stop , stop Docker, and then enter the following commands.

step.cmd: Enable and start the Dnsmasq package.
step.info: The package facilitates networking among Docker containers.

stepxmp.codeblock: systemctl enable dnsmasq && systemctl start dnsmasq

step.info: If name resolution in your environment relies solely on entries in /etc/hosts, configure dsnmasq so that containers can use the file:

substep.cmd: Open /etc/dnsmasq.conf with a text editor.
Locate the line that starts with #domain-needed, and then make a copy of the line, immediately below the original.
Locate the line that starts with #bogus-priv, and then make a copy of the line, immediately below the original.
Locate the line that starts with #local=/localnet/, and then make a copy of the line, immediately below the original.
Remove net, and then remove the number sign character (#) from the beginning of the line.
Locate the line that starts with #domain=example.com, and then make a copy of the line, immediately below the original.
Replace example.com with local, and then remove the number sign character (#) from the beginning of the line.
Restart the dnsmasq service.

stepxmp.codeblock: ip addr show docker0 | grep inet

substep.cmd: Open /etc/sysconfig/docker in a text editor.
Add the following flags to the end of the OPTIONS declaration.

stepxmp.p: Replace Bridge-Subnet with the IPv4 subnet docker selected for its virtual bridge:

substep.info: For example, if the bridge subnet is 172.17.0.1, add the following flags: --dns=172.17.0.1 --bip=172.17.0.1/16
